It's easier to go down a hill than go up, but the view is better at the top.

Hut I!
Hut II!!
HIKE!!!
At last year's Ad-Hoc Committee on
Common Space, Sue Martin, Director of the
MSE Library, suggested that the cafeteria in
AMR I be converted into an undergraduate
reading room. But students objected because
they wanted to study far, far away from the
familiar surroundings of the dorms—
freshmen because they lived there and upperclassmen because they used to live there.
Now Martin has another suggestion. She
wants to convert the Garrett Room into an
undergraduate reading room. But students
are objecting again because they want to
study far, far away from the sterile surroundings of the MSE Library.
Two years. Two suggestions. Two ways
to get rid of the Hutzler Undergraduate
Library as the undergraduate reading room.
And both times, students have objected, but
this time, the problem is more serious. Last
year's suggestion was just that—a
suggestion—but this year's suggestion has
turned into a proposal, already submitted to
President Steven Muller and to Provost and
Vice President of Academic Affairs Richard
Longaker. And that's the problem. The administration, once again, has neglected to
consult with the students. They didn't consult With students when they reorganized the
dean structure nor did they consult with
students when they selected the deans. So
why should this time be any different? The
administration is succeeding at being consistent, but unfortunately, reputations result
from consistent actions, and the administration is getting a reputation of not listening
to students, or better yet, of not seeking
students' opinions.
Issue after issue, the administration says
they want to make improvements which
would benefit both students and faculty.
Well, this time, the improvements would be
at the expense of a sacred campus
institution—an institution that's been part
of Hopkins for 20 years.
To be sure, the MSE Library needs more
room, but converting the Hut into a Special
Collections Room and converting the Garrett Room into a combination reading
room/reserve room is not the solution.
It appears that the administration wants
to make Gilman Hall a showplace with the
Special Collections Room as its centerpiece.
During the summer of 1985, the dean of the
arts and sciences and the dean of engineering are scheduled to move into the east wing
of Gilman. At the same time, the other
deans, along with the political economy, the
political science, and the sociology departments, will move to Mergenthaler Hall'.
Thus, Gilman will house the humanities
departments, the two principle deans, and
either Hut I or Hut II.
Hut I is a place where students socialize
and study, both during the day and at night.
During the day, students either sit in the coffee shop area or in the Hut itself. They wait,
for upcoming classes. Or they talk. Or they
read magazines and newspapers. Or they

finish assignments. Or they just relax. 'They'
even includes many faculty members who
also, not surprisingly, enjoy reading
periodicals, flip through reference books,
and drink tea at the coffee shop which will
be moved if Hut I becomes Hut II.
Hut II will be an air-conditioned Special
Collections Room with rare books occupying one-third of it and carpet and chairs occupying two-thirds of it. Air conditioning is
the only reason people would want to stay
in Hut II. Rare books, because of the acid
in their pages, tend to deteriorate if they
aren't stored properly. Hut I currently is not
air-conditioned. Instead, large fans prevent
people from deteriorating during hot
weather.
Hut II will be a place where receptions can
be held and where the Trustees can meet.
There's no other reason to house rare books
in a Special Collections Room. Hut II will
be a reception area with a showcase to impress people. And that's all.
Since Hut II will not be open 24 hours and
since it will be too fancy(most likely, smoking will not be allowed because of the rare
books), students will have to go to the Garrett Room (most likely, smoking will not be
allowed because of the small area) which will
be a combination reading room/reserve
room, open 24 hours. The present reserve
room and map room on M level will then
provide more space for students to study
during the regular library hours, but this additional space won't be available between
midnight and eight in the morning. Thus,
students won't be able to take reserve
material out of the noisy and crowded Garrett Room. Currently, most students read
reserve material elsewhere. So the library will
have to change the reserve policy or install
a few photocopying machines.
The Garrett Room's conversion will also
decrease the amount of available meeting
space on campus, which is already a problem. Using rooms in Levering Hall is a
nossibility, but so is converting some of those
rooms into reading rooms.
Yes, more space is needed for books. Yes,
more space is needed for students to study.
Yes, rare books are important, and they
should be stored in a central location.
But other aspects of campus, especially
those aspects affecting social life, should also
be considered. The Rat. The Student Union.
The Glass Pavilion. The Great Hall. And the
list goes on. As Dean of Arts and Sciences
George Fisher said, "Everything must be
condidered as a package."
The solution is not simple. Students, faculty members, and administrators must sit
down and talk about the future. Until that
happens, communication will continue to he
the main problem on this campus.
But for now, the Hutzler Undergraduate
Library must be preserved as the Hut and
not as a museum for a Special Books
Collection.

Ratting on the Thieves
To the Editor:
When I read the article in last
week's News-Letter concerning
the rats that were stolen from
Ames Hall, I was mortified. It
never ceases to amaze me how
some people can be so stupid
and have such a limited
mentality.
I wonder if the members of
the Animal Liberation Front
know how many of their
relatives are alive today thanks
to the "pointless and repulsive"
experiments that have been performed on laboratory animals.
I wonder if they know how
many vaccines they themselves
have been treated with that
were developed and tested in
laboratory animals. I do not
think that they do.
It did my heart good to read
the quote from the press release
issued by the Animal Liberation Front: "during the
Christmas season there can be
no peace on earth as long as we
continue to destroy this planet
and its inhabitants."
How then can there be peace
as long as little children go to
bed hungry every night and
wake up to an empty breakfast
table every morning of every
season of the year? If the efforts of these, "do-gooders"
were shifted from stealing
laboratory rats to stopping pain
and suffering of human beings
throughout the world, then
maybe all those children would
not have to die of hunger each
year and "peace on earth"
could be achieved.
We must remember that the
needs of the many outweigh the
needs of the few, or better yet,
the needs of the human race
outweigh the needs of the
animal race.
However, being an animal
lover myself, I must be fair and
offer a suggestion to reduce the
pain and suffering of these
poor creatures while still saving
the lives that medical research
does each year; therefore, I
propose that we free all
laboratory animals and use the
members of the Animal Liberation Front for all these
"pointless" experiments.
I am sure they would agree

since they are so committed to
saving these animals. Besides, it
would save money and show us
exactly what effect the treatment will have on humans instead of using animals as
models.
Sincerely,
Jim Pellicane

The horseshoe crab's blood is
a valuable tool in speeding up
diagnosis of bacterial related

A Walkersville, Maryland,

using the horseshoe crab's
blood to prepare pharmaceutical kits that are used
around the world to screen for
pyrogens. Dr. Ronald Berzofsky, who heads the laboratory's
horseshoe crab project, explains that the horseshoe crabs
are first picked up three or four
miles off the coast of Chincoteague, Virginia, then are
shipped to a laboratory for
bleeding, and are finally returned uninjured to the sea. The
horseshoe crabs are collected
twice a week and only between
the months of April and August
when they are most plentiful
along the coast. An average
day's catch is four hundred
horseshoe crabs, of which the
average animal size is two and
a half feet in diameter.
The horseshoe crab does not
have a heart and has an open
circulatory system. Blood is
drawn via a needle from a
membraneous sac at the hinge
joining the anterior to the back
shell. After blood is drawn, the
horseshoe crab's blood cells,
called amebocytes, are isolated
and an extract is made from
these cells. It is the extract
which is actually used in testing
solutions for the presence of
pyrogens.
Through research, the contents of the amebocyte extract
and the biochemistry of the
clotting process have become
fairly well understood. Simply
put, a proenzyme present in the
amebocytes reacts with a
pyrogen to forni an active enzyme. This active enzyme acts
to cleave a clotting protein of
the amebocyte into specific
fragments. These fragments
then interact to form a threedimensional matrix—that is,
the clot.
The tests may be made quantitative by adding to the extract
another protein which reacts
with (he active enzyme and produces a yellow color. The intensity of the yellow color increases with pyrogen concentration. By measuring the
intensity—that
is,
the
absorbance—of the resulting
solution, one obtains an indirect measure of the pyrogen
concentration.
Though the horseshoe crab's
blood has only been sought
after for a short period of time,
its importance in medical
research is undeniable. So the
next time you see a horseshoe
crab stranded on the beach,
throw it back into the sea. One
day it may donate blood for
you.

Never Cry Wolf is a much
better movie than it should be.
There are an awful lot of things
wrong with it, but it is one of
the best movies I have seen in
the past year. First, it is
cinematographically beautiful.
I suppose it isn't difficult ot
find pretty camera work in
Alaska, but in Never Cry Wolf,
even the indoor photography is
good. Unlike most movies that
are "beautiful", Never Cry
Wolf isn't boring.
Never Cry Wolf is about a
naturalist, Tyler (Charles Martin Smith), who is looking for
an adventure. He volunteers to
track a pack of Arctic wolves
for the government, which
believes that wolves are responsible for the decimation of the
caribou. He is dropped in the
middle of the Alaskan mountains in late winter with a
canoe, ten crates of supplies,
and his base oboe, which he intends to play for the wolves. He
establishes "Lupus Base One"
outside a den inhabited by two
handsome Arctic wolves, whom
he names George and Angie,
and their pups, who are not appallingly cute. I was impressed
by the fact that the movie never
tries to make the animals seem

cute or "human", which is
especially surprising considering this is a Disney movie.
Tyler becomes convinced
that the wolves are not killing
many caribou and in fact live
largely on field mice. There is
a very funny sequence when
Tyler decides to prove that a
large mammal can live on field
mice, using himself as the test
animal. He sets an elegant
table, the best silver and china,
a carafe of moose-juice(a blend
of Moosehead beer and grain
alcohol), and a tureen of mouse
stew. Later he becomes even
more of a gourmet, preparing
for himself such delicacies as
mouse brochette, mouse-on-aritz, and mouse au vin.
The movie doesn't really go
anywhere. Tyler convinces
himself that the wolves are only eating the sick caribou,
though he doesn't think he will
be able to convince the government. It doesn't really matter
though, because in a little while
the area will probably be
bulldozed and paved over by
corrupt Man, typified by the
vicious pilot, Rosie (played with
ambiguous malice by Brian
Dennehy). Eventually, Tyler
wanders off with Unuk, a Inoit
(Eskimo) who saved his life early during the winter.

There are serious problems
with the movie. It is a Walt
Disney release, and has an old
Walt Disney plot: a man of
civilization becomes a part of
the wilderness. The voice-over
narration is atrocious; it makes
Tyler, who acts intelligent,
sound like a fool, and doesn't
help the movie along at all. No
fewer than three writers pooled their incompetence to write
the narration, and whatever effort they might have put into it
doesn't show.
Sometimes the movie takes
itself too seriously: dream sequences, mysterious black
wolves, ancient Indian legends,
the kind of stuff that makes
bad movies really bad, all
weaken this good movie. Some
of Tyler's discussions with the
old Inoit ("The wolf, it is my
guardian spirit") are ridiculous
because the audience is supposed to believe this garbage.
Perhaps some people do accept
hokiness as authenticity; I just
forgave it on the grounds that
there were so many other things
about the movie that were
likeable and authentic.
Never Cry Wolf is playing at
the Rotunda ($2 student admission, Monday through Thursday) and I definitely recommend you go see it.

Winter Olympics: Fun and Games In Sarajevo
by -Joel Greenwald
Researching sports on Dlevel is usually an ordinary procedure. This was not to be the
case this past Wednesday evening. Beyond the stacks labeled
PQ-PR came a humming
sound, becoming increasingly
loud and clear. Aha, it occurred to me what I was hearing—
dum dum...te dum...dum dum
dum...Jim McKay...the Olympic flame...Sarajevo... —but
who was responsible for this
glorious sound in the forbidden
bowels of D-level?
As more voices joined in, I
saw it—an unbelievable
sight—sixty-five of the most ardent D-level regulars chanting
at the top of their lungs. If you
listened hard enough you could

hear the trumpets coming
through the airducts of C-level.
Seniors at Hopkins had told me
of a similar event taking place
four years earlier on the eve of
Lake Placid.
Fifteen of these pre-meds
converged on a couch in the
lounge area in the far end, and
almost mechanically they torched it—their very own Olympic
flame. The floor was suddenly
empty, and it became evident
that the four year hibernation
had ended..for a fortnight at
least.
The sight of the 1984 Winter
Sarajevo,
Olympics,
Yugoslavia is known for two
things besides snow. First,
Sarajevo was the locale for the
assassination that began WWI,
and second, it is the only city in

the world that serves fried eggs
on pizza (no joke).
Events at this year's games
should have a special relevence
to a university such as JHU.
This is a campus where small
sports seem to get particular attention. This is also the case
with the Winter Olympics,
where lesser known sports come
out of the woodwork.
Hopkins has made the local'
news with their concern over a
hockey team. Similarly, Olympic Hockey gets more than its
share of publicity. Who cares if
five Olympic Hockey players
were suspended from the games
for signing NHL contracts? I
want to know who's looking
good in the two-man luge trials.
Luge racking is easily the
most dangerous of all the

winter games, as was evidenced by a death at Lake Placid in
1980. The Swiss seem to always
do well in luge-racing (probably
because that's how they slide
down the Alps to buy the morning newspaper).
Bob-sled racing is invariably
won by East Germans named
Wolfgang, Heinz or Heinz
Wolfgang (German equivalent
to American hero ketchup ratpack). I hate events dominated
by Nazis on steroids.
When Dick Button, the ABC
rodent, starts on about triple
loops in the figure skating
events, I take my bathroom
break. Give me ice-dancing,
and I can't keep the popcorn in
my mouth—true thrills every
minute.
All these sports are fun;

alpine skiing is bearable; but
my favorite event is unquestionably the biathelon (say
what!).
Yes, that's right, a medieval
sport that combines crosscountry skiing with target
shooting. Countless letters have
been written to ABC to give this
ancient sport more coverage.
This sport, long dominated
by Siberian policemen is wide
open this year. They have been
threatening for years, but the
question persists: will Luxembourg finally take the coveted
gold medal?
Get excited campus! D-level
can't be responsible for 'all'
your fun.

No matter who anyone roots
for this year, their second
choice has to be for the Geritol
coach from Chicago, Ray
Meyer.
Ray is the guy the networks
book more than his team, the
DePaul Blue Demons. He's on
the tube six or seven times a
year, because they know every
person with grey hair from
Portland to Poughkeepsie will
turn the dial to watch this
remarkable senior citizen who's
still in the hunt.
Ray Meyer turned 70 last
December, as he started his
42nd and final season at
his
Currently
DePaul.
undefeated Blue Demons are
ranked number two in the nation. He's become only the fifth
major college coach to record
more than 700 career victories,
and if he takes DePaul to the
Final Four in Seattle, they've
got to be the sentimental
favorite.
But no matter where Ray
Meyer finishes, he's a
winner—first class, a Park
Avenue person with class and
thoroughbred manners—a
gentleman. le a career as both
player and coach that has
spanned six decades, he can be
justly proud.
So let's give him his due now,
this Frank Skeffington of the
Hardwood. It's his last hurrah.
It's only too bad Spencer Tracy
can't be around to do his life
story, after the crepe paper sags
and the last blue and white confetti of the season is swept
away.
Ray Meyer is truly the elder
statesman of basketball, the last
coach to remember black high
top sneakers, knee pads,
wooden blackboards, and
games on black-and -white TV.
He did not invent the sport of
basketball, but when Dr.
Naismith was putting up the
peach basket, Ray Meyer was
holding the ladder.
He is truly the last of the
Mohicans, because it is a rare
breed of cat who can still control the whistle and clipboard in
the heavyweight division long
after most coaches have accepted the gold watch and
caught the train to Sun City.
The pressures Ray Meyer has
withstood are tremendous.
Most coaches are taking early
leave or being pushed out in
their 30's, or being burnt in effigy in their 40's, or after one
winning season in their 50's,
retire and live off that. In their
60's, there aren't any around
down in the pit—and Ray
Meyer is 70.
He's still going through what
Rich Najerus is going through
at Marquette, what Bobby
Knight is going through at Indiana, what Dean Smith is going through at North Carolina,

and what Ralph Miller is going
through at Oregon State. It's
just that Rick is in his 30's,
Bobby Knight in his 50's, and
Ralph Miller in his 60's—and
Ray Meyer is 70.
Coach Meyer is a rare and
unique man, who has lived his
whole life by a simple code of
values. He's had only one
house, one wife, and one job.
He's an old-neighborhood
man, houses with stoops,
milkmen putting bottles on the
front porch, Ed Sullivan on
Sunday nights, a family man
who attends every wake.
What makes Ray special is
that he has super-exceeded the
coaching image on a novenaand-rosary budget, and never
got involved in the rush-tobank philosophy of coaching.
He still does the father-son,
Moose, Eagle, Elk, Boy Scouts,
United Way, you name it. He's
a soft touch that way, and these
groups know when in doubt,
call Ray. He'll do what has to
be done, no fee.
He is the most recognizable
figure in the game today. When
you say "coach" in Chicago, it
means Ray Meyer, not the guy
at Northwestern or Notre Dame
or chicago Circle. Ask a cabbie:
"You think Coach can make
the Final Four?" He'll start
talking about DePaul. Saying
coach in Chicago is like saying,
Wilt, Bird, Magic. There's only one person that comes to
mind.
Ray's teams were always
prepared and, above all, his
players were taught how to lose
with dignity and win with
humility. The familiar picture
of Ray after a game, hitching
up his belt before he met the
press, either to take the blame

for his team's losses or to praise
his players for a winning performance, will stay with us
forever.
It's easy to be graceful when
you win. I've seen Ray in heartbreak losses, where he never
refused to come on TV, even
though maybe his number one
ranked team had just been
knocked out of the tournament
by St. Joseph's. It was a terrible blow, but Ray handled it
with grace. He has that dignr
ty, that way about him, we shall
never see again.
When I was at Marquette
and we coached against each
other, we were great friends.
But for two hours twice a year,
we put on different hats, our
game faces, and went at it. We
both had a style of yelling at the
ballplayers. At the half, our
lockers were next to each other.
So Ray would yell a while, then
I'd yell a while.
I remember his great sense of
humor. When we played in the
Old DePaul gym, the
washroom was between both
teams' locker rooms. Once, I
was doing my pre-game radio
show with Tom Collins, and in
the middle of the taping, Ray
walked in and flushed all the
johns. That ended the interview
quick.
Coach Meyer has won every
major award. In 1978, he was
named Coach of the Year by
the US Basketball Writers
Association, and he was inducted into the Naismith Hall
of Fame in 1979. That same
year, he was named Chicagoan
of the Year by the Chicago
Press Club. He took his team to
the NCAA Final Four in 1979,
and to the NIT Finals in 1983.
Next year, Coach Meyer
passes on the baton to his son
Joey, who has been his top
assistant for 10 years, patient
and well-schooled. So this year,
wherever his team plays, you
should go see him. Take your
children and say, "There is a
man who has stood the test of
time and has been a credit to a
profession that has few lasting
idols."
As you watch him, try to
take a mind's eye picture. It's
the last time around.

At last year's Ad-Hoc Committee on
Common Space, Sue Martin, Director of the
MSE Library, suggested that the cafeteria in
AMR I be converted into an undergraduate
reading room. But students objected because
they wanted to study far, far away from the
familiar surroundings of the dorms—
freshmen because they lived there and upperclassmen because they used to live there.
Now Martin has another suggestion. She
wants to convert the Garrett Room into an
undergraduate reading room. But students
are objecting again because they want to
study far, far away from the sterile surroundings of the MSE Library.
Two years. Two suggestions. Two ways
to get rid of the Hutzler Undergraduate
Library as the undergraduate reading room.
And both times, students have objected, but
this time, the problem is more serious. Last
year's suggestion was just that—a
suggestion—but this year's suggestion has
turned into a proposal, already submitted to
President Steven Muller and to Provost and
Vice President of Academic Affairs Richard
Longaker. And that's the problem. The administration, once again, has neglected to
consult with the students. They didn't consult With students when they reorganized the
dean structure nor did they consult with
students when they selected the deans. So
why should this time be any different? The
administration is succeeding at being consistent, but unfortunately, reputations result
from consistent actions, and the administration is getting a reputation of not listening
to students, or better yet, of not seeking
students' opinions.
Issue after issue, the administration says
they want to make improvements which
would benefit both students and faculty.
Well, this time, the improvements would be
at the expense of a sacred campus
institution—an institution that's been part
of Hopkins for 20 years.
To be sure, the MSE Library needs more
room, but converting the Hut into a Special
Collections Room and converting the Garrett Room into a combination reading
room/reserve room is not the solution.
It appears that the administration wants
to make Gilman Hall a showplace with the
Special Collections Room as its centerpiece.
During the summer of 1985, the dean of the
arts and sciences and the dean of engineering are scheduled to move into the east wing
of Gilman. At the same time, the other
deans, along with the political economy, the
political science, and the sociology departments, will move to Mergenthaler Hall'.
Thus, Gilman will house the humanities
departments, the two principle deans, and
either Hut I or Hut II.
Hut I is a place where students socialize
and study, both during the day and at night.
During the day, students either sit in the coffee shop area or in the Hut itself. They wait,
for upcoming classes. Or they talk. Or they
read magazines and newspapers. Or they

finish assignments. Or they just relax. 'They'
even includes many faculty members who
also, not surprisingly, enjoy reading
periodicals, flip through reference books,
and drink tea at the coffee shop which will
be moved if Hut I becomes Hut II.
Hut II will be an air-conditioned Special
Collections Room with rare books occupying one-third of it and carpet and chairs occupying two-thirds of it. Air conditioning is
the only reason people would want to stay
in Hut II. Rare books, because of the acid
in their pages, tend to deteriorate if they
aren't stored properly. Hut I currently is not
air-conditioned. Instead, large fans prevent
people from deteriorating during hot
weather.
Hut II will be a place where receptions can
be held and where the Trustees can meet.
There's no other reason to house rare books
in a Special Collections Room. Hut II will
be a reception area with a showcase to impress people. And that's all.
Since Hut II will not be open 24 hours and
since it will be too fancy(most likely, smoking will not be allowed because of the rare
books), students will have to go to the Garrett Room (most likely, smoking will not be
allowed because of the small area) which will
be a combination reading room/reserve
room, open 24 hours. The present reserve
room and map room on M level will then
provide more space for students to study
during the regular library hours, but this additional space won't be available between
midnight and eight in the morning. Thus,
students won't be able to take reserve
material out of the noisy and crowded Garrett Room. Currently, most students read
reserve material elsewhere. So the library will
have to change the reserve policy or install
a few photocopying machines.
The Garrett Room's conversion will also
decrease the amount of available meeting
space on campus, which is already a problem. Using rooms in Levering Hall is a
nossibility, but so is converting some of those
rooms into reading rooms.
Yes, more space is needed for books. Yes,
more space is needed for students to study.
Yes, rare books are important, and they
should be stored in a central location.
But other aspects of campus, especially
those aspects affecting social life, should also
be considered. The Rat. The Student Union.
The Glass Pavilion. The Great Hall. And the
list goes on. As Dean of Arts and Sciences
George Fisher said, "Everything must be
condidered as a package."
The solution is not simple. Students, faculty members, and administrators must sit
down and talk about the future. Until that
happens, communication will continue to he
the main problem on this campus.
But for now, the Hutzler Undergraduate
Library must be preserved as the Hut and
not as a museum for a Special Books
Collection.

a valuable tool in speeding up
diagnosis of bacterial related

A Walkersville, Maryland,
laboratory, near Frederick, is
one of four or five in the nation
using the horseshoe crab's
blood to prepare pharmaceutical kits that are used
around the world to screen for
pyrogens. Dr. Ronald Berzofsky, who heads the laboratory's
horseshoe crab project, explains that the horseshoe crabs
are first picked up three or four
miles off the coast of Chincoteague, Virginia, then are
shipped to a laboratory for
bleeding, and are finally returned uninjured to the sea. The
horseshoe crabs are collected
twice a week and only between
the months of April and August
when they are most plentiful
along the coast. An average
day's catch is four hundred
horseshoe crabs, of which the
average animal size is two and
a half feet in diameter.
The horseshoe crab does not
have a heart and has an open
circulatory system. Blood is
drawn via a needle from a
membraneous sac at the hinge
joining the anterior to the back
shell. After blood is drawn, the
horseshoe crab's blood cells,
called amebocytes, are isolated
and an extract is made from
these cells. It is the extract
which is actually used in testing
solutions for the presence of
pyrogens.
Through research, the contents of the amebocyte extract
and the biochemistry of the
clotting process have become
fairly well understood. Simply
put, a proenzyme present in the
amebocytes reacts with a
pyrogen to forni an active enzyme. This active enzyme acts
to cleave a clotting protein of
the amebocyte into specific
fragments. These fragments
then interact to form a threedimensional matrix—that is,
the clot.
The tests may be made quantitative by adding to the extract
another protein which reacts
with (he active enzyme and produces a yellow color. The intensity of the yellow color increases with pyrogen concentration. By measuring the
intensity—that
is,
the
absorbance—of the resulting
solution, one obtains an indirect measure of the pyrogen
concentration.
Though the horseshoe crab's
blood has only been sought
after for a short period of time,
its importance in medical
research is undeniable. So the
next time you see a horseshoe
crab stranded on the beach,
throw it back into the sea. One
day it may donate blood for
you.

Never Cry Wolf
by Michael Lorton
Never Cry Wolf is a much
better movie than it should be.
There are an awful lot of things
wrong with it, but it is one of
the best movies I have seen in
the past year. First, it is
cinematographically beautiful.
I suppose it isn't difficult ot
find pretty camera work in
Alaska, but in Never Cry Wolf,
even the indoor photography is
good. Unlike most movies that
are "beautiful", Never Cry
Wolf isn't boring.
Never Cry Wolf is about a
naturalist, Tyler (Charles Martin Smith), who is looking for
an adventure. He volunteers to
track a pack of Arctic wolves
for the government, which
believes that wolves are responsible for the decimation of the
caribou. He is dropped in the
middle of the Alaskan mountains in late winter with a
canoe, ten crates of supplies,
and his base oboe, which he intends to play for the wolves. He
establishes "Lupus Base One"
outside a den inhabited by two
handsome Arctic wolves, whom
he names George and Angie,
and their pups, who are not appallingly cute. I was impressed
by the fact that the movie never
tries to make the animals seem

cute or "human", which is
especially surprising considering this is a Disney movie.
Tyler becomes convinced
that the wolves are not killing
many caribou and in fact live
largely on field mice. There is
a very funny sequence when
Tyler decides to prove that a
large mammal can live on field
mice, using himself as the test
animal. He sets an elegant
table, the best silver and china,
a carafe of moose-juice(a blend
of Moosehead beer and grain
alcohol), and a tureen of mouse
stew. Later he becomes even
more of a gourmet, preparing
for himself such delicacies as
mouse brochette, mouse-on-aritz, and mouse au vin.
The movie doesn't really go
anywhere. Tyler convinces
himself that the wolves are only eating the sick caribou,
though he doesn't think he will
be able to convince the government. It doesn't really matter
though, because in a little while
the area will probably be
bulldozed and paved over by
corrupt Man, typified by the
vicious pilot, Rosie (played with
ambiguous malice by Brian
Dennehy). Eventually, Tyler
wanders off with Unuk, a Inoit
(Eskimo) who saved his life early during the winter.

There are serious problems
with the movie. It is a Walt
Disney release, and has an old
Walt Disney plot: a man of
civilization becomes a part of
the wilderness. The voice-over
narration is atrocious; it makes
Tyler, who acts intelligent,
sound like a fool, and doesn't
help the movie along at all. No
fewer than three writers pooled their incompetence to write
the narration, and whatever effort they might have put into it
doesn't show.
Sometimes the movie takes
itself too seriously: dream sequences, mysterious black
wolves, ancient Indian legends,
the kind of stuff that makes
bad movies really bad, all
weaken this good movie. Some
of Tyler's discussions with the
old Inoit ("The wolf, it is my
guardian spirit") are ridiculous
because the audience is supposed to believe this garbage.
Perhaps some people do accept
hokiness as authenticity; I just
forgave it on the grounds that
there were so many other things
about the movie that were
likeable and authentic.
Never Cry Wolf is playing at
the Rotunda ($2 student admission, Monday through Thursday) and I definitely recommend you go see it.

by Al McGuire
No matter who anyone roots
for this year, their second
choice has to be for the Geritol
coach from Chicago, Ray
Meyer.
Ray is the guy the networks
book more than his team, the
DePaul Blue Demons. He's on
the tube six or seven times a
year, because they know every
person with grey hair from
Portland to Poughkeepsie will
turn the dial to watch this
remarkable senior citizen who's
still in the hunt.
Ray Meyer turned 70 last
December, as he started his
42nd and final season at
his
Currently
DePaul.
undefeated Blue Demons are
ranked number two in the nation. He's become only the fifth
major college coach to record
more than 700 career victories,
and if he takes DePaul to the
Final Four in Seattle, they've
got to be the sentimental
favorite.
But no matter where Ray
Meyer finishes, he's a
winner—first class, a Park
Avenue person with class and
thoroughbred manners—a
gentleman. le a career as both
player and coach that has
spanned six decades, he can be
justly proud.
So let's give him his due now,
this Frank Skeffington of the
Hardwood. It's his last hurrah.
It's only too bad Spencer Tracy
can't be around to do his life
story, after the crepe paper sags
and the last blue and white confetti of the season is swept
away.
Ray Meyer is truly the elder
statesman of basketball, the last
coach to remember black high
top sneakers, knee pads,
wooden blackboards, and
games on black-and -white TV.
He did not invent the sport of
basketball, but when Dr.
Naismith was putting up the
peach basket, Ray Meyer was
holding the ladder.
He is truly the last of the
Mohicans, because it is a rare
breed of cat who can still control the whistle and clipboard in
the heavyweight division long
after most coaches have accepted the gold watch and
caught the train to Sun City.
The pressures Ray Meyer has
withstood are tremendous.
Most coaches are taking early
leave or being pushed out in
their 30's, or being burnt in effigy in their 40's, or after one
winning season in their 50's,
retire and live off that. In their
60's, there aren't any around
down in the pit—and Ray
Meyer is 70.
He's still going through what
Rich Najerus is going through
at Marquette, what Bobby
Knight is going through at Indiana, what Dean Smith is going through at North Carolina,

and what Ralph Miller is going
through at Oregon State. It's
just that Rick is in his 30's,
Bobby Knight in his 50's, and
Ralph Miller in his 60's—and
Ray Meyer is 70.
Coach Meyer is a rare and
unique man, who has lived his
whole life by a simple code of
values. He's had only one
house, one wife, and one job.
He's an old-neighborhood
man, houses with stoops,
milkmen putting bottles on the
front porch, Ed Sullivan on
Sunday nights, a family man
who attends every wake.
What makes Ray special is
that he has super-exceeded the
coaching image on a novenaand-rosary budget, and never
got involved in the rush-tobank philosophy of coaching.
He still does the father-son,
Moose, Eagle, Elk, Boy Scouts,
United Way, you name it. He's
a soft touch that way, and these
groups know when in doubt,
call Ray. He'll do what has to
be done, no fee.
He is the most recognizable
figure in the game today. When
you say "coach" in Chicago, it
means Ray Meyer, not the guy
at Northwestern or Notre Dame
or chicago Circle. Ask a cabbie:
"You think Coach can make
the Final Four?" He'll start
talking about DePaul. Saying
coach in Chicago is like saying,
Wilt, Bird, Magic. There's only one person that comes to
mind.
Ray's teams were always
prepared and, above all, his
players were taught how to lose
with dignity and win with
humility. The familiar picture
of Ray after a game, hitching
up his belt before he met the
press, either to take the blame

for his team's losses or to praise
his players for a winning performance, will stay with us
forever.
It's easy to be graceful when
you win. I've seen Ray in heartbreak losses, where he never
refused to come on TV, even
though maybe his number one
ranked team had just been
knocked out of the tournament
by St. Joseph's. It was a terrible blow, but Ray handled it
with grace. He has that dignr
ty, that way about him, we shall
never see again.
When I was at Marquette
and we coached against each
other, we were great friends.
But for two hours twice a year,
we put on different hats, our
game faces, and went at it. We
both had a style of yelling at the
ballplayers. At the half, our
lockers were next to each other.
So Ray would yell a while, then
I'd yell a while.
I remember his great sense of
humor. When we played in the
Old DePaul gym, the
washroom was between both
teams' locker rooms. Once, I
was doing my pre-game radio
show with Tom Collins, and in
the middle of the taping, Ray
walked in and flushed all the
johns. That ended the interview
quick.
Coach Meyer has won every
major award. In 1978, he was
named Coach of the Year by
the US Basketball Writers
Association, and he was inducted into the Naismith Hall
of Fame in 1979. That same
year, he was named Chicagoan
of the Year by the Chicago
Press Club. He took his team to
the NCAA Final Four in 1979,
and to the NIT Finals in 1983.
Next year, Coach Meyer
passes on the baton to his son
Joey, who has been his top
assistant for 10 years, patient
and well-schooled. So this year,
wherever his team plays, you
should go see him. Take your
children and say, "There is a
man who has stood the test of
time and has been a credit to a
profession that has few lasting
idols."
As you watch him, try to
take a mind's eye picture. It's
the last time around.
